title: Do you type faster on your phone or on your PC? - Quora

response.answer_text: I can type way faster on a computer keyboard with autocorrect turned off. I type incredibly fast on a real keyboard and rarely ever have to look at the keyboard, or even the screen. I can close my eyes and type more accurately and faster than I can on a smartphone. I’m not kidding. On a smartphone or tablet, I find I spend 3/4 of the time correcting autocorrect. If I turn off autocorrect it’s really no better. If I take the time to look at the suggestions, it slows me down and can knock me out of my train of thought. A tablet is marginally better than an iPhone. I took touch-typing in junior high summer school way back in the late 60s. My parents made me. I had to type my term papers in college on an electric typewriter in college. We couldn’t use correction tape or white out. This made for accurate typing. Word processors weren’t common until my second professional job. I used to write code on a computer keyboard from 1977–2006; I rarely had to look at the screen. Brain to code actualized. I can type pretty fast on a tablet or iPhone screen, but do have issues with autocorrect seemingly randomly inserting names from my contact list. I’ve watched in awe as if goes back and change things I’ve typed correctly. It almost always puts in “Tim” when I type a “t” and will change “do” to “don’t”. The list is endless. “I” becomes “Ismaili,” which, ironically took me four tries to type in when I wanted to! Good becomes Goodman, and it’s adding “s” contraction and entire suffixes to be “helpful.” “That” becomes “that’s” or even “that’ll.” They becomes they’re. “Becomes” becomes “become s”. Etc. . This slows me down, a lot. Obviously. The real issue for me is that typing on a smartphone or tablet makes me pause to deal with the mechanics and lose track of the content. For example, when typing the previous sentence, autocorrect went back and changed “typing on” to “typhoon game”. WTF. What real keyboards have that screens don’t is tactile feedback, spacial certainty, and special clues. There are raised dots in most key boards that identify home keys. The mechanical keys move and or click when depressed. You never have to worry what the computer will do if you hit the “I” and “o” key at same time. Your touch either one or the other, not both, In the very old days, the typewriter keys would jam if you pressed two at once, so you learned quickly not to do so. Now, the computer uses some nerd’s algorithms to guess what you meant to type. Computer keyboards are big enough for your hands and the meaning of keys don’t change as you work. A p is a p is a p. You KNOW when you’ve hit a key and there is a good chance your fingers are in the right position. The keyboard won’t helpfulky add letters to words. This is the recipe for speed and accuracy’s.

It’s aids. It is quite hard to compare. Also… I wouldn’t really call it typing unless you hold your phone like this  This isn’t Typing:  That is barbarically using your thumb to smash buttons on a flat piece of glass. And the probability of you misspelling a word is much high than on a standard keyboard. This is a KeyBoard: It has real Keys on a real Board They go down when you press them, and when they reach a certain point, they register. Often a bump and/or audible click are felt heard.  This is Not a keyboard. This what I would call a Virtual Button board. Look Closely:  There are no Keys and No board (well, kinda, I guess the pone is a board itself) But the buttons here don’t press, they don’t bump, they don’t click, nothing. Its just a hit or miss. And they are 1/5th the size of a real Keyboard Key. Which means it is much harder to hit them. A phone keyboard is just a virtual imitation of a real keyboard. But they are handy, for sure. But the typing is not the same. Definitely go for the Keyboard rather than a phone. if you have a choice. often you don’t.

Based on some sample data I collected and conversations with colleagues and friends. Most people can type between 30–50 words per minute on a PC/laptop with some practice. People who are good at typing can probably reach 70–100 words per minute (the best typists can reach much higher than that)On the phone, actual “typing” won’t get you close to those speeds. But if you are using predictive text typing or speech to text, you could possibly go much faster (accuracy may suffer and depends on how well you can make it work)So, in summary, most people can with some practice generally type faster on the PC, but in the near future, that difference might not be much especially if speech to text recognition and other techniques get really accurate (Note: These could work on both PC and phone)

I’d say I would rather be able to type faster on my computer because of a few reasons. I already do :) and there’s literally no way that I can type faster on my phone now…I think it makes more sense to be able to type faster on your computer because you’re using all 10 fingers in contrast to just two when you type on your phone…I spend more time on my computer in general.When I type on my phone, it’s mainly to call people or send short messages, so typing speed doesn’t matter much (also my phone is somewhat old so the screen just freezes when I type too fast).Computers are more useful than phones in the long run, plus you can get a bluetooth keyboard for your phone, and your typing speed will be transferred over. :)

Phone. A lot of times I'm sitting on front of the PC and using phone. For example right now with Quora. Mostly because I'm using SwiftKey keyboard on the phone. It does excellent prediction of what I'm typing from my own vocabulary. This is what different with this particular keyboard. Majority does general predictions. SwiftKey learns what you type. It starts working well only after few weeks of usage. So instead of typing in most of the cases all I'm doing is picking words. P. S Just for info. My phone is Note 4. Screen is big enough.

Personally, I’m an old guy that learned to type on a manual typewriter. I find it almost impossible to type on a phone. I use most of my fingers on a computer keyboard. On a phone, my fingers cover about 2 keys so I can’t tell what key I pressed. I can hunt-and-peck with a capacitative stylus which is a bit better, but much much slower than on a physical keyboard. I can use my thumbs on my old tablet with chiclet keys, but my thumbnails don’t trigger a phone screen. Having said that, I think the current typing speed record is held by someone using a swipe keyboard on a tablet.

It depends on specific device and perspective - I've always been a quite proficient typist, testing myself out of typing class back in high school by essentially whiffing through the exam even though I technically never learned ‘proper typing form’ as most of my peers had to endure for entire semester… However when I first got an iPhone it did take me a while to transition but on my newer iPhone 7 Plus with the large screen larger keyboard I feel that I'm able to play much more quickly but still not as fast in comparison to a full-size keyboard on a desktop PC or laptop

Computer, with proper typing style for following reasons you will be using almost all fingers on pc, on phone you will be using two thumbs at maxyou will have a real key board with the key stroke feed back and real feelmore space on pc keyboard
